elements.content: Hierarchically porous metal–organic frameworks (HP-MOFs) are promising in many applications. However, most previous studies focus on HP-MOFs with two kinds of pore structures. Herein, a strategy for efficient construction of HP-MOFs possessing macro-meso-micropores using template-assisted spray drying followed by etching process is proposed. Taking ZIF-8 as an example, using polystyrene (PS) templates, the complete HP-ZIF-8 with all the three categories of pores can be easily fabricated. The close arrangement of intrinsic microporous nanosized ZIF-8 (N-ZIF-8) in the spray drying process results in the creation of mesopores, while the macropores are further generated after the removal of PS templates. The structures of macropores and mesopores can be easily adjusted by altering the size and proportion of PS and the size of N-ZIF-8, respectively. Furthermore, this method is extended to the preparation of HP-HKUST-1. As a proof-of-concept, HP-ZIF-8 displays excellent catalytic properties in Knoevenagel reaction owing to its unique pore features. Compared with conventional microsized ZIF-8 (M-ZIF-8) with similar size, HP-ZIF-8 achieves the significantly increased conversion of benzaldehyde from 55% to 100% within 3 h, and shows better recycling performance than N-ZIF-8.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), as one of the state-of-the-art porous functional hybrid materials, have exhibited a great promise in gas storage, adsorption separation, catalysis, sensor, medicine, energy storage, and so on, thanks to their rich variety and precision designed structure. The pore sizes of most MOFs are primarily adjustable within a microporous range (<2 nm). This inherent microporosity is conducive to the adsorption and separation of small guest molecules, but hinders their mass transfer and diffusion in the pores. In addition, it also blocks the entrance of larger molecules to the pores to interact with the preferential active sites in frameworks, which greatly limits their applications, especially in adsorption and catalysis.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), as one of the state-of-the-art porous functional hybrid materials, have exhibited a great promise in gas storage, adsorption separation, catalysis, sensor, medicine, energy storage, and so on, thanks to their rich variety and precision designed structure. The pore sizes of most MOFs are primarily adjustable within a microporous range (<2 nm). This inherent microporosity is conducive to the adsorption and separation of small guest molecules, but hinders their mass transfer and diffusion in the pores. In addition, it also blocks the entrance of larger molecules to the pores to interact with the preferential active sites in frameworks, which greatly limits their applications, especially in adsorption and catalysis.

elements.content: In order to overcome this limitation, hierarchically porous MOFs (HP-MOFs), formed by introducing large pores (mesopores and/or macropores) into MOFs have attracted much attention because of the optimized diffusion process and well-defined porosity. However, at present, the majority of research focuses on HP-MOFs possessing two kinds of pore structures, such as MOFs with micro- and mesoporous structures, or with micro- and macroporous structures, and limits in the synthesis of MOFs integrated with the mentioned all three categories of pores. The macropores in HP-MOFs are desired for achieving rapid diffusion and mass transfer of molecules. This is very significant for those applications related to larger molecules and viscous fluids. Therefore, to deal with this challenge, it is very crucial to develop a convenient and efficient approach for the synthesis of HP-MOFs containing tunable micropores, mesopores, and macropores.
elements.clean_text: In order to overcome this limitation, hierarchically porous MOFs (HP-MOFs), formed by introducing large pores (mesopores and/or macropores) into MOFs have attracted much attention because of the optimized diffusion process and well-defined porosity. However, at present, the majority of research focuses on HP-MOFs possessing two kinds of pore structures, such as MOFs with micro- and mesoporous structures, or with micro- and macroporous structures, and limits in the synthesis of MOFs integrated with the mentioned all three categories of pores. The macropores in HP-MOFs are desired for achieving rapid diffusion and mass transfer of molecules. This is very significant for those applications related to larger molecules and viscous fluids. Therefore, to deal with this challenge, it is very crucial to develop a convenient and efficient approach for the synthesis of HP-MOFs containing tunable micropores, mesopores, and macropores.

elements.content: So far, many approaches have been exploited, such as ligand expansion/exchange, etching, template synthesis, etc. Linker extension strategy was first proposed to synthesize HP-MOFs. A series of IRMOFs with hierarchically porous structures can be obtained through the substitution of BDC (1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) with some expanded linkers. The pore size of the HP-MOFs synthesized by this method is mainly tunable in the range of less than 10 nm. In recent years, solvent etching and template strategies have been adopted as the construction of porous structures. HP-MOFs with diverse pore structures were thus synthesized. However, it is still challenging to exploit an efficient and scalable approach for preparing HP-MOFs.

The pore size of the HP-MOFs synthesized by this method is mainly tunable in the range of less than 10 nm. In recent years, solvent etching and template strategies have been adopted as the construction of porous structures. HP-MOFs with diverse pore structures were thus synthesized. However, it is still challenging to exploit an efficient and scalable approach for preparing HP-MOFs.

elements.content: Spray drying is a well-known industrial technique, which is considered as a rapid large-scale method for the continuous preparation of different materials. It is a process of using hot compressed air to quickly remove the solvent in the droplets followed by collecting the dried/structured products, which has been universally applied in many fields, including medicine, food, and materials. Recently, we reported a simple spray-drying assisted method for fast fabrication of HP-MOFs with both kinds of pores by adopting MOFs nanoparticles as building blocks. Herein, we further propose an updated approach for preparing HP-MOFs with macro-meso-microporous structures by using PS as the macropore templates in the spray drying, followed by etching process. The introduction of macropores can further accelerate diffusion and mass transfer of molecules within the material, thereby achieving its high-performance applications. Taking ZIF-8 as an example, the mesopores of HP-ZIF-8 are formed by aggregation of nanosized ZIF-8 (N-ZIF-8) during spray drying, which can be adjusted by altering the initial particle size of N-ZIF-8. Meanwhile, the macropores are formed after PS is removed, which can be tuned by altering the size of PS templates and mass proportion of N-ZIF-8/PS. In addition, this method is also extended to the successful preparation of HP-HKUST-1. As a proof-of-concept, Knoevenagel reaction is carried out using HP-ZIF-8 as the catalyst. Compared to conventional microporous ZIF-8 (M-ZIF-8), HP-ZIF-8 shows greatly improved catalytic performance due to the constructed mesopores and macropores, and exhibits better recycling performance than N-ZIF-8.

elements.content: Methanol (MeOH), styrene (St), toluene, N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), and ethanol (EtOH) were bought from Beijing Chemical Reagent (China), and the polymerization inhibitor in St was removed using alkaline alumina. Benzaldehyde, malononitrile, sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS), potassium persulfate (KPS), 2-methylimidazole, and zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology (China). The above reagents were used as received and do not need further purification.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

Methanol (MeOH), styrene (St), toluene, N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), and ethanol (EtOH) were bought from Beijing Chemical Reagent (China), and the polymerization inhibitor in St was removed using alkaline alumina. Benzaldehyde, malononitrile, sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS), potassium persulfate (KPS), 2-methylimidazole, and zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology (China). The above reagents were used as received and do not need further purification.

elements.content: For N-ZIF-8–20, Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (733.2 mg) and 2-methylimidazole (1.62 g) were dissolved in 100 mL MeOH, respectively. The two solutions were blended and agitated for 50 min at room temperature. For N-ZIF-8–40, Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (1.47 g) and 2-methylimidazole (3.24 g) were dissolved in 100 mL MeOH, respectively. Both solutions were blended and agitated for 30 min at room temperature. For N-ZIF-8–70, Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (734.4 mg) and 2-methylimidazole (810.6 mg) were added to 50 mL MeOH, respectively. After blending and agitating for 2 min, the above solution was allowed to stand for 1 h at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of N-ZIF-8

For N-ZIF-8-20, Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (733.2 mg) and 2-methylimidazole (1.62 g) were dissolved in 100 mL MeOH, respectively. The two solutions were blended and agitated for 50 min at room temperature. For N-ZIF-8-40, Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (1.47 g) and 2-methylimidazole (3.24 g) were dissolved in 100 mL MeOH, respectively. Both solutions were blended and agitated for 30 min at room temperature. For N-ZIF-8-70, Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (734.4 mg) and 2-methylimidazole (810.6 mg) were added to 50 mL MeOH, respectively. After blending and agitating for 2 min, the above solution was allowed to stand for 1 h at room temperature.

elements.content: In order to remove the 2-methylimidazole molecules remaining in the pores, the suspension was further centrifuged. The collected white products were soaked in MeOH for 72 h. During this period, the solvent was replaced with fresh MeOH three times a day. The N-ZIF-8 powder was achieved after drying at 423 K for 12 h.
elements.clean_text: In order to remove the 2-methylimidazole molecules remaining in the pores, the suspension was further centrifuged. The collected white products were soaked in MeOH for 72 h. During this period, the solvent was replaced with fresh MeOH three times a day. The N-ZIF-8 powder was achieved after drying at 423 K for 12 h.

elements.content: Emulsion polymerization method was used to prepare PS particles. First, 500 mL flask with 3 °C reflux condenser was placed in a 65 °C water bath, and then purged with N2. Subsequently, a mixture of 65 mg SDS, 200 mL EtOH, and 100 mL deionized water was poured into this flask and agitated at 200 rpm. Finally, St monomers (8 mL) and KPS (0.3 g) were successively added to the flask. After the whole reaction process lasting for 11 h, the resulting white suspension was further washed with EtOH several times to remove the surface emulsifier. The wet solid was collected by centrifuging, which was transferred to water to form a dispersion.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of PS (400 nm)

Emulsion polymerization method was used to prepare PS particles. First, 500 mL flask with 3 °C reflux condenser was placed in a 65 °C water bath, and then purged with N2. Subsequently, a mixture of 65 mg SDS, 200 mL EtOH, and 100 mL deionized water was poured into this flask and agitated at 200 rpm. Finally, St monomers (8 mL) and KPS (0.3 g) were successively added to the flask. After the whole reaction process lasting for 11 h, the resulting white suspension was further washed with EtOH several times to remove the surface emulsifier. The wet solid was collected by centrifuging, which was transferred to water to form a dispersion.

elements.content: The solvent is deionized water and the N-ZIF-8 and PS suspensions were mixed and sonicated for several seconds, and then injected into the spray dryer under certain conditions: feed rate of 22.5 mL min–1, inlet temperature of 100 °C, compressed air flow rate of 536 L h–1 and latex particle concentration of 2 wt %. ZIF-8@PS was collected in the collection vessel. Finally, 100 mg ZIF-8@PS was immersed in 8 mL DMF and agitated at 80 °C for 60 min to eliminate PS templates. The formed HP-ZIF-8 was obtained by centrifugation and further dried at 423 K under a vacuum oven.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of HP-ZIF-8

The solvent is deionized water and the N-ZIF-8 and PS suspensions were mixed and sonicated for several seconds, and then injected into the spray dryer under certain conditions: feed rate of 22.5 mL min-1, inlet temperature of 100 °C, compressed air flow rate of 536 L h-1 and latex particle concentration of 2 wt %. ZIF-8@PS was collected in the collection vessel. Finally, 100 mg ZIF-8@PS was immersed in 8 mL DMF and agitated at 80 °C for 60 min to eliminate PS templates. The formed HP-ZIF-8 was obtained by centrifugation and further dried at 423 K under a vacuum oven.

elements.content: The catalytic reaction was performed between benzaldehyde and malononitrile as reactants in a magnetically stirred glassy bottle (20 mL) using HP-ZIF-8 as catalyst. Typically, a mixture of HP-ZIF-8 (20 mg) and toluene (5 mL) was placed and agitated for 5 min to make HP-ZIF-8 dispersed in the solvent. Then, benzaldehyde (0.2 mL) and malononitrile (0.238 mL) were poured into the above mixture, respectively. The reactants were agitated for 8 h at room temperature. The same aliquot was taken out at a specific time point, filtered with a short silica gel, and then analyzed by GC-MS to determine reaction conversion.
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic Performance in Knoevenagel Reactions

The catalytic reaction was performed between benzaldehyde and malononitrile as reactants in a magnetically stirred glassy bottle (20 mL) using HP-ZIF-8 as catalyst. Typically, a mixture of HP-ZIF-8 (20 mg) and toluene (5 mL) was placed and agitated for 5 min to make HP-ZIF-8 dispersed in the solvent. Then, benzaldehyde (0.2 mL) and malononitrile (0.238 mL) were poured into the above mixture, respectively. The reactants were agitated for 8 h at room temperature. The same aliquot was taken out at a specific time point, filtered with a short silica gel, and then analyzed by GC-MS to determine reaction conversion.

elements.content:
For the recyclability test, the catalyst was recycled by centrifugation, washed using toluene, and dried to remove the residual solvent. The collected catalyst was reused in the following run.

Characterization

Scanning electron microscope (SEM) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEOL-7800, Japan) were used to observe the morphology of the samples. The surface areas were obtained according to Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method using Beishide 3H-2000PS2 at 77 K (pressure range: 0.01–0.1). The pore size distributions were achieved by Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) model, nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) model, and mercury intrusion porosimetry, respectively. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a TG-DTA 8122. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD, XRD-6000, Shimadzu, Japan) patterns were recorded by an Ultima IV instrument. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrum was recorded in the range 500–3500 cm–1 by a Nicolet 6700 spectrometer. GC-MS evaluations were carried out by a Thermo Fisher ISQ Trace 1300 with a DB-WAX column.
elements.clean_text:
For the recyclability test, the catalyst was recycled by centrifugation, washed using toluene, and dried to remove the residual solvent. The collected catalyst was reused in the following run.

Characterization

Scanning electron microscope (SEM) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEOL-7800, Japan) were used to observe the morphology of the samples. The surface areas were obtained according to Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method using Beishide 3H-2000PS2 at 77 K (pressure range: 0.01-0.1). The pore size distributions were achieved by Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model, nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) model, and mercury intrusion porosimetry, respectively. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a TG-DTA 8122. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD, XRD-6000, Shimadzu, Japan) patterns were recorded by an Ultima IV instrument. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrum was recorded in the range 500-3500 cm-1 by a Nicolet 6700 spectrometer. GC-MS evaluations were carried out by a Thermo Fisher ISQ Trace 1300 with a DB-WAX column.

elements.content: The schematic diagram for the preparation process of HP-MOFs is presented with an example of ZIF-8 (). First, as the raw material of spray drying, nanosized ZIF-8 (about 20 nm, N-ZIF-8–20, Supporting Information (SI) Figure S1) and PS (SI Figure S2) suspensions are mixed in a certain proportion. The obtained aqueous suspension is further spray-dried for the construction of superstructures (ZIF-8@PS). The obtained ZIF-8@PS is then soaked in DMF to remove the PS templates. This resulting unique structured MOF is denoted as HP-ZIF-8–20 (x, y), in which x and y represent the particle size of PS and the mass ratio of N-ZIF-8–20/PS, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Preparation of HP-ZIF-8 Using Template-Assisted Spray Drying Strategy

The schematic diagram for the preparation process of HP-MOFs is presented with an example of ZIF-8 (). First, as the raw material of spray drying, nanosized ZIF-8 (about 20 nm, N-ZIF-8-20, Supporting Information (SI) Figure S1) and PS (SI Figure S2) suspensions are mixed in a certain proportion. The obtained aqueous suspension is further spray-dried for the construction of superstructures (ZIF-8@PS). The obtained ZIF-8@PS is then soaked in DMF to remove the PS templates. This resulting unique structured MOF is denoted as HP-ZIF-8-20 (x, y), in which x and y represent the particle size of PS and the mass ratio of N-ZIF-8-20/PS, respectively.

elements.content: As shown in a–c, N-ZIF-8–20 and PS are closely packed to form dense ZIF-8@PS microspheres with an average size of ∼2.0 μm (SI Figure S3). After etching, HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) with uniform pore structure is obtained (d–f). The TEM results of ZIF-8@PS and HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) (c,f) also confirm that the sprayed superstructure changes from solid structure to porous structure, and the corresponding macropores formed after PS removal exhibit an average size of approximate 400 nm. The elemental mapping images (g) show a uniform distribution of elements containing N, C, and Zn in the whole HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) particles.
elements.clean_text: As shown in a-c, N-ZIF-8-20 and PS are closely packed to form dense ZIF-8@PS microspheres with an average size of ~2.0 μm (SI Figure S3). After etching, HP-ZIF-8-20 (400, 4) with uniform pore structure is obtained (d-f). The TEM results of ZIF-8@PS and HP-ZIF-8-20 (400, 4) (c,f) also confirm that the sprayed superstructure changes from solid structure to porous structure, and the corresponding macropores formed after PS removal exhibit an average size of approximate 400 nm. The elemental mapping images (g) show a uniform distribution of elements containing N, C, and Zn in the whole HP-ZIF-8-20 (400, 4) particles.

elements.content: (a–c) SEM and TEM images of ZIF-8@PS; (d,e) SEM, (f) TEM, and (g) element mapping images of HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4).
elements.clean_text: 1  (a-c) SEM and TEM images of ZIF-8@PS; (d,e) SEM, (f) TEM, and (g) element mapping images of HP-ZIF-8-20 (400, 4).

elements.content: The PXRD patterns confirm good crystallinity of HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4), well matching the N-ZIF-8–20 and simulated one (a). In addition, the same FTIR spectra of HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) and N-ZIF-8–20 indicate that the four characteristic peaks belonging to the phenyl ring of PS disappeared (b), proving that PS is completely removed. HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) was further investigated by nitrogen-sorption measurements (c). HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) and ZIF-8@PS show similar type IV isotherms at P/P0 of ∼0.05 and ∼0.95, demonstrating the existence of mesopores in the two products, which is ascribed to the occurrence of capillary condensation in the mesopores. And it increases sharply at very low relative pressure, which is consistent with the uniform microporous characteristics of ZIF-8. This confirms that micropores and mesopores of HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) keep unchanged after etching. The distributions of micropores, mesopores, and macropores of the products were tested by NLDFT, BJH, and mercury intrusion porosimetry. As shown in d–f, the formed mesopores and macropores have sizes of about 9 and 400 nm, respectively. The formation of mesopores is due to the close arrangement of N-ZIF-8–20 particles in the spray drying process. Moreover, HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) has the BET surface area and pore volume of 1646.3 m2 g–1 and 1.28 cm3 g–1, respectively, which slightly increase compared with those of N-ZIF-8–20 (1537.7 m2 g–1 and 0.95 cm3 g–1) (SI Figure S4). As a result, HP-ZIF-8 including macro-meso-microporous structure is thus obtained after etching. TGA and DTG results (SI Figure S5) of HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) indicate that HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) decomposes thermally at 600 °C to form zinc oxide. Under the same treatment conditions, the weight losses of HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) and N-ZIF-8–20 are similar. SEM image, N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms, and pore size distribution of HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) after being calcined at 300 °C (SI Figure S6) prove that the skeleton can maintain thermal stability at this temperature.

elements.content: In order to obtain high-quality ultimate product of HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4), the structure and morphology of intermediate ZIF-8@PS are very important. The spray drying parameters, including inlet temperature, compressed air flow rate, feed rate, and solid content need to be regulated to form ZIF-8@PS with a spherical shape. As can be seen from a–c, with the temperature rising from 100 to 140 °C, the morphology of ZIF-8@PS changes from sphere to doughnut. This is possibly because the increase of temperature results in the enhancement of surface tension and the increase of droplet instability. d–f show SEM images of ZIF-8@PS obtained in various feed rates. For a high feed rate (22.5 mL min–1, f), ZIF-8@PS demonstrates a uniform spherical shape. In contrast, some ring-shaped and irregular particles appear with the decrease of feed rate (d). This is because when the water on the droplet surface evaporates, the weak interaction between particles cannot compensate the inward force of internal particle water evaporation, resulting in the inward shrinkage of the shell and the formation of irregular particles. In addition, with increasing solid content from 1 wt % to 3 wt % and the flow rate from 473 L h–1 to 601 L h–1, the morphology of ZIF-8@PS changes slightly (SI Figure S7).

The spray drying parameters, including inlet temperature, compressed air flow rate, feed rate, and solid content need to be regulated to form ZIF-8@PS with a spherical shape. As can be seen from a-c, with the temperature rising from 100 to 140 °C, the morphology of ZIF-8@PS changes from sphere to doughnut. This is possibly because the increase of temperature results in the enhancement of surface tension and the increase of droplet instability. d-f show SEM images of ZIF-8@PS obtained in various feed rates. For a high feed rate (22.5 mL min-1, f), ZIF-8@PS demonstrates a uniform spherical shape. In contrast, some ring-shaped and irregular particles appear with the decrease of feed rate (d). This is because when the water on the droplet surface evaporates, the weak interaction between particles cannot compensate the inward force of internal particle water evaporation, resulting in the inward shrinkage of the shell and the formation of irregular particles. In addition, with increasing solid content from 1 wt % to 3 wt % and the flow rate from 473 L h-1 to 601 L h-1, the morphology of ZIF-8@PS changes slightly (SI Figure S7).

elements.content: In order to regulate macropore size and structure, the effects of PS template size and mass ratio of N-ZIF-8/PS were explored. a–d show HP-ZIF-8 formed in N-ZIF-8–20/PS of 4:1, with PS particle sizes of 100, 300, 400, and 600 nm (SI Figure S2), respectively. As expected, the formed macropore size increases with PS particle size, demonstrating that the size of macropores can be readily adjusted by altering the diameter of PS used. However, further increasing PS particle size results in the formation of aspherical particles and fragmented particles (d). This is because after the PS templates are removed, the connection between the remaining N-ZIF-8 particles is extremely fragile, leading to the fracture of the HP-ZIF-8 framework. e–h show SEM images of the HP-ZIF-8 prepared with PS (400 nm) and N-ZIF-8–20/PS mass ratios of 3:1 to 6:1. The number of macropores rises with the increase of PS ratio. However, the excessive mass ratio disrupts the macroporous structure of the HP-ZIF-8 (e). When a large number of PS accumulates in ZIF-8@PS, after the templates are removed, the shell of the superstructure becomes very thin and then shrinks or collapses inward. Therefore, the optimum balance required for the production of highly uniform HP-ZIF-8 is N-ZIF-8/PS = 4 and the size of PS is 400 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Pore Structure Adjustment

In order to regulate macropore size and structure, the effects of PS template size and mass ratio of N-ZIF-8/PS were explored. a-d show HP-ZIF-8 formed in N-ZIF-8-20/PS of 4:1, with PS particle sizes of 100, 300, 400, and 600 nm (SI Figure S2), respectively. As expected, the formed macropore size increases with PS particle size, demonstrating that the size of macropores can be readily adjusted by altering the diameter of PS used. However, further increasing PS particle size results in the formation of aspherical particles and fragmented particles (d). This is because after the PS templates are removed, the connection between the remaining N-ZIF-8 particles is extremely fragile, leading to the fracture of the HP-ZIF-8 framework. e-h show SEM images of the HP-ZIF-8 prepared with PS (400 nm) and N-ZIF-8-20/PS mass ratios of 3:1 to 6:1. The number of macropores rises with the increase of PS ratio. However, the excessive mass ratio disrupts the macroporous structure of the HP-ZIF-8 (e). When a large number of PS accumulates in ZIF-8@PS, after the templates are removed, the shell of the superstructure becomes very thin and then shrinks or collapses inward. Therefore, the optimum balance required for the production of highly uniform HP-ZIF-8 is N-ZIF-8/PS = 4 and the size of PS is 400 nm.

elements.content: In addition, the influence of initial nanoparticles on mesoporous structure of HP-ZIF-8 was further explored. Nanosized ZIF-8 particles of 40 nm (N-ZIF-8–40, SI Figure S1) and 70 nm (N-ZIF-8–70, SI Figure S1) were synthesized. HP-ZIF-8–40 (400, 4) and HP-ZIF-8–70 (400, 4) were obtained by the same strategy, as shown in a,b. PXRD patterns of HP-ZIF-8–40 (400, 4) and HP-ZIF-8–70 (400, 4) are in good accordance with that of the simulated one (c). It can be confirmed from d and SI Figure S8 that with the increase of the initial N-ZIF-8 size from 20 to 70 nm, the mesoporous pore sizes increase from 9 nm, 14 nm to 24 nm, respectively.

HP-ZIF-8-40 (400, 4) and HP-ZIF-8-70 (400, 4) were obtained by the same strategy, as shown in a,b. PXRD patterns of HP-ZIF-8-40 (400, 4) and HP-ZIF-8-70 (400, 4) are in good accordance with that of the simulated one (c). It can be confirmed from d and SI Figure S8 that with the increase of the initial N-ZIF-8 size from 20 to 70 nm, the mesoporous pore sizes increase from 9 nm, 14 nm to 24 nm, respectively.

elements.content: To confirm the universality of this strategy, HKUST-1@PS and HP-HKUST-1 with macro-meso-microporous structures were further prepared using the same strategy (a–c). The PXRD patterns of HP-HKUST-1 and nanosized HKUST-1 (N-HKUST-1) are the same as the simulated one, implying that HP-HKUST-1 has good crystallinity (d). The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of HP-HKUST-1 demonstrate the existence of micropores and mesopores (e,f). Therefore, this method has great potential in constructing single or composite MOFs with hierarchical pore structures by using one or more kinds of nanosized MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of HP-HKUST-1

To confirm the universality of this strategy, HKUST-1@PS and HP-HKUST-1 with macro-meso-microporous structures were further prepared using the same strategy (a-c). The PXRD patterns of HP-HKUST-1 and nanosized HKUST-1 (N-HKUST-1) are the same as the simulated one, implying that HP-HKUST-1 has good crystallinity (d). The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of HP-HKUST-1 demonstrate the existence of micropores and mesopores (e,f). Therefore, this method has great potential in constructing single or composite MOFs with hierarchical pore structures by using one or more kinds of nanosized MOFs.

elements.content: To further demonstrate the structure advantage of HP-ZIF-8 with macro-meso-microporous structures, the catalytic experiments were performed based on the Knoevenagel reaction. As shown in a, HP-ZIF-8 exhibits significantly enhanced activities compared with M-ZIF-8 (SI Figure S9). The benzaldehyde can be completely converted in 3 h for the HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) and N-ZIF-8–20, whereas only 72% conversion is achieved for M-ZIF-8 after 8 h (SI Figure S10). Furthermore, with the increased macropore diameter of HP-ZIF-8–20 from 100 to 400 nm, the reaction efficiency increases and the reaction time is obviously shortened from 6 to 3 h. The obvious difference in catalytic performances suggests that the improved catalytic efficiency may benefit from the unique pore structure and larger BET surface area of HP-ZIF-8 (SI Table S1 and SI Figure S11), which offer larger channels to accelerate the diffusion of molecules in the material. Compared with the traditional microsized ZIF-8, HP-ZIF-8 provides more accessible active sites. Compared to N-ZIF-8–20, HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) has similar catalytic efficiency that the conversion of benzaldehyde is completed within 3 h. However, HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) exhibits much better recyclability than N-ZIF-8–20. HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) can be recycled at least five times (b), and the conversion of benzaldehyde only decreases from 96.1 to 82.9% in 3 h. In contrast, a decrease of >5% in catalytic performance is observed in every following run for N-ZIF-8–20 and decreases to 60% after 5 cycles. Owing to the small particle size of N-ZIF-8–20 and wall hanging in the Knoevenagel reaction process, N-ZIF-8–20 is difficult to be centrifuged in the recovery process, which is the main reason for its poor recyclability. The PXRD pattern and SEM image show the pristine and constructed hierarchical porous structures are both well preserved after catalytic cycling (c,d). As shown in d,e, the BET surface area and pore size distribution of HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) after reaction are about 1634 m2 g–1 and 7 nm, respectively, which are not much different from those before reaction.
elements.clean_text:
Knoevenagel Reaction Performance

To further demonstrate the structure advantage of HP-ZIF-8 with macro-meso-microporous structures, the catalytic experiments were performed based on the Knoevenagel reaction. As shown in a, HP-ZIF-8 exhibits significantly enhanced activities compared with M-ZIF-8 (SI Figure S9). The benzaldehyde can be completely converted in 3 h for the HP-ZIF-8-20 (400, 4) and N-ZIF-8-20, whereas only 72% conversion is achieved for M-ZIF-8 after 8 h (SI Figure S10). Furthermore, with the increased macropore diameter of HP-ZIF-8-20 from 100 to 400 nm, the reaction efficiency increases and the reaction time is obviously shortened from 6 to 3 h. The obvious difference in catalytic performances suggests that the improved catalytic efficiency may benefit from the unique pore structure and larger BET surface area of HP-ZIF-8 (SI Table S1 and SI Figure S11), which offer larger channels to accelerate the diffusion of molecules in the material. Compared with the traditional microsized ZIF-8, HP-ZIF-8 provides more accessible active sites. Compared to N-ZIF-8-20, HP-ZIF-8-20 (400, 4) has similar catalytic efficiency that the conversion of benzaldehyde is completed within 3 h. However, HP-ZIF-8-20 (400, 4) exhibits much better recyclability than N-ZIF-8-20. HP-ZIF-8-20 (400, 4) can be recycled at least five times (b), and the conversion of benzaldehyde only decreases from 96.1 to 82.9% in 3 h. In contrast, a decrease of >5% in catalytic performance is observed in every following run for N-ZIF-8-20 and decreases to 60% after 5 cycles. Owing to the small particle size of N-ZIF-8-20 and wall hanging in the Knoevenagel reaction process, N-ZIF-8-20 is difficult to be centrifuged in the recovery process, which is the main reason for its poor recyclability. The PXRD pattern and SEM image show the pristine and constructed hierarchical porous structures are both well preserved after catalytic cycling (c,d). As shown in d,e, the BET surface area and pore size distribution of HP-ZIF-8-20 (400, 4) after reaction are about 1634 m2 g-1 and 7 nm, respectively, which are not much different from those before reaction.

elements.content: Additionally, ZIF-8 superstructures containing micropores and mesopores were also used as the catalyst for this reaction, but the complete conversion of benzaldehyde takes 6 h (a). Then the reaction was carried out using 13, 20, and 30 mg (1, 3, 5 mol % relative to benzaldehyde) of HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) as the catalyst. As shown in b, by increasing the amount of catalyst from 13 to 30 mg, the conversion increases from 76 to 100% within 2 h. Then, the effect of the malononitrile/benzaldehyde molar ratio (1:1, 2:1, and 3:1) on reaction conversions is explored (SI Figure S12) (keep the content of benzaldehyde constant). The results show that the maximum reaction conversion (100%) of the benzaldehyde is obtained at 3:1 within 1 h. The benzaldehyde conversion in Knoevenagel reaction over various catalysts is compared in . Clearly, the as-prepared HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) with macro-meso-microporous structures has a higher conversion of benzaldehyde at a lower reaction temperature, shorter time, and less catalyst, which shows much better catalytic property than most of the previously reported catalysts except ordered single-crystal ZIF-8 with macro-microporous structures (SOM-ZIF-8).

In summary, a straightforward and convenient strategy has been proposed to successfully fabricate HP-MOFs with macro-meso-microporous structures using template-assisted spray drying for the first time. The mesopores are formed by the accumulation of N-MOF particles in the spray drying process and can be adjusted by altering the initial N-MOF size. By adjusting the PS particle size, the macroporous pore size of HP-MOFs can change from 100 to 400 nm, and the number of pores in HP-MOFs can be controlled by changing the N-MOFs/templates mass ratios. The construction of HP-HKUST-1 confirms the versatility of this strategy. Moreover, the obtained HP-ZIF-8 displays excellent catalytic properties for Knoevenagel reaction. Compared with M-ZIF-8, HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) exhibits the greatly improved conversion of benzaldehyde from 55% to 100% within 3 h and has much better recyclability than N-ZIF-8–20. It could be anticipated that this strategy would offer new insights into the fabrication of a number of HP-MOFs with different compositions and functionalities.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a straightforward and convenient strategy has been proposed to successfully fabricate HP-MOFs with macro-meso-microporous structures using template-assisted spray drying for the first time. The mesopores are formed by the accumulation of N-MOF particles in the spray drying process and can be adjusted by altering the initial N-MOF size. By adjusting the PS particle size, the macroporous pore size of HP-MOFs can change from 100 to 400 nm, and the number of pores in HP-MOFs can be controlled by changing the N-MOFs/templates mass ratios. The construction of HP-HKUST-1 confirms the versatility of this strategy. Moreover, the obtained HP-ZIF-8 displays excellent catalytic properties for Knoevenagel reaction. Compared with M-ZIF-8, HP-ZIF-8-20 (400, 4) exhibits the greatly improved conversion of benzaldehyde from 55% to 100% within 3 h and has much better recyclability than N-ZIF-8-20. It could be anticipated that this strategy would offer new insights into the fabrication of a number of HP-MOFs with different compositions and functionalities.

cln_elements.content:
For N-ZIF-8–20, Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (733.2 mg) and 2-methylimidazole (1.62 g) were dissolved in 100 mL MeOH, respectively. The two solutions were blended and agitated for 50 min at room temperature. For N-ZIF-8–40, Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (1.47 g) and 2-methylimidazole (3.24 g) were dissolved in 100 mL MeOH, respectively. Both solutions were blended and agitated for 30 min at room temperature. For N-ZIF-8–70, Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (734.4 mg) and 2-methylimidazole (810.6 mg) were added to 50 mL MeOH, respectively. After blending and agitating for 2 min, the above solution was allowed to stand for 1 h at room temperature.

Synthesis of PS (400 nm)

Emulsion polymerization method was used to prepare PS particles. First, 500 mL flask with 3 °C reflux condenser was placed in a 65 °C water bath, and then purged with N2. Subsequently, a mixture of 65 mg SDS, 200 mL EtOH, and 100 mL deionized water was poured into this flask and agitated at 200 rpm. Finally, St monomers (8 mL) and KPS (0.3 g) were successively added to the flask. After the whole reaction process lasting for 11 h, the resulting white suspension was further washed with EtOH several times to remove the surface emulsifier. The wet solid was collected by centrifuging, which was transferred to water to form a dispersion.

Synthesis of HP-ZIF-8

The solvent is deionized water and the N-ZIF-8 and PS suspensions were mixed and sonicated for several seconds, and then injected into the spray dryer under certain conditions: feed rate of 22.5 mL min–1, inlet temperature of 100 °C, compressed air flow rate of 536 L h–1 and latex particle concentration of 2 wt %. ZIF-8@PS was collected in the collection vessel. Finally, 100 mg ZIF-8@PS was immersed in 8 mL DMF and agitated at 80 °C for 60 min to eliminate PS templates. The formed HP-ZIF-8 was obtained by centrifugation and further dried at 423 K under a vacuum oven.

Synthesis of N-ZIF-8

For N-ZIF-8-20, Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (733.2 mg) and 2-methylimidazole (1.62 g) were dissolved in 100 mL MeOH, respectively. The two solutions were blended and agitated for 50 min at room temperature. For N-ZIF-8-40, Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (1.47 g) and 2-methylimidazole (3.24 g) were dissolved in 100 mL MeOH, respectively. Both solutions were blended and agitated for 30 min at room temperature. For N-ZIF-8-70, Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (734.4 mg) and 2-methylimidazole (810.6 mg) were added to 50 mL MeOH, respectively. After blending and agitating for 2 min, the above solution was allowed to stand for 1 h at room temperature.

Emulsion polymerization method was used to prepare PS particles. First, 500 mL flask with 3 °C reflux condenser was placed in a 65 °C water bath, and then purged with N2. Subsequently, a mixture of 65 mg SDS, 200 mL EtOH, and 100 mL deionized water was poured into this flask and agitated at 200 rpm. Synthesis of HP-ZIF-8

The solvent is deionized water and the N-ZIF-8 and PS suspensions were mixed and sonicated for several seconds, and then injected into the spray dryer under certain conditions: feed rate of 22.5 mL min-1, inlet temperature of 100 °C, compressed air flow rate of 536 L h-1 and latex particle concentration of 2 wt %. cln_elements.content:
The PXRD patterns confirm good crystallinity of HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4), well matching the N-ZIF-8–20 and simulated one (a). In addition, the same FTIR spectra of HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) and N-ZIF-8–20 indicate that the four characteristic peaks belonging to the phenyl ring of PS disappeared (b), proving that PS is completely removed. HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) was further investigated by nitrogen-sorption measurements (c). HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) and ZIF-8@PS show similar type IV isotherms at P/P0 of ∼0.05 and ∼0.95, demonstrating the existence of mesopores in the two products, which is ascribed to the occurrence of capillary condensation in the mesopores. And it increases sharply at very low relative pressure, which is consistent with the uniform microporous characteristics of ZIF-8. This confirms that micropores and mesopores of HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) keep unchanged after etching. The distributions of micropores, mesopores, and macropores of the products were tested by NLDFT, BJH, and mercury intrusion porosimetry. As shown in d–f, the formed mesopores and macropores have sizes of about 9 and 400 nm, respectively. The formation of mesopores is due to the close arrangement of N-ZIF-8–20 particles in the spray drying process. Moreover, HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) has the BET surface area and pore volume of 1646.3 m2 g–1 and 1.28 cm3 g–1, respectively, which slightly increase compared with those of N-ZIF-8–20 (1537.7 m2 g–1 and 0.95 cm3 g–1) (SI Figure S4). As a result, HP-ZIF-8 including macro-meso-microporous structure is thus obtained after etching. TGA and DTG results (SI Figure S5) of HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) indicate that HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) decomposes thermally at 600 °C to form zinc oxide. Under the same treatment conditions, the weight losses of HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) and N-ZIF-8–20 are similar. SEM image, N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms, and pore size distribution of HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) after being calcined at 300 °C (SI Figure S6) prove that the skeleton can maintain thermal stability at this temperature.

Knoevenagel Reaction Performance

To further demonstrate the structure advantage of HP-ZIF-8 with macro-meso-microporous structures, the catalytic experiments were performed based on the Knoevenagel reaction. As shown in a, HP-ZIF-8 exhibits significantly enhanced activities compared with M-ZIF-8 (SI Figure S9). The benzaldehyde can be completely converted in 3 h for the HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) and N-ZIF-8–20, whereas only 72% conversion is achieved for M-ZIF-8 after 8 h (SI Figure S10). Furthermore, with the increased macropore diameter of HP-ZIF-8–20 from 100 to 400 nm, the reaction efficiency increases and the reaction time is obviously shortened from 6 to 3 h. The obvious difference in catalytic performances suggests that the improved catalytic efficiency may benefit from the unique pore structure and larger BET surface area of HP-ZIF-8 (SI Table S1 and SI Figure S11), which offer larger channels to accelerate the diffusion of molecules in the material. Compared with the traditional microsized ZIF-8, HP-ZIF-8 provides more accessible active sites. Compared to N-ZIF-8–20, HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) has similar catalytic efficiency that the conversion of benzaldehyde is completed within 3 h. However, HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) exhibits much better recyclability than N-ZIF-8–20. HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) can be recycled at least five times (b), and the conversion of benzaldehyde only decreases from 96.1 to 82.9% in 3 h. In contrast, a decrease of >5% in catalytic performance is observed in every following run for N-ZIF-8–20 and decreases to 60% after 5 cycles. Owing to the small particle size of N-ZIF-8–20 and wall hanging in the Knoevenagel reaction process, N-ZIF-8–20 is difficult to be centrifuged in the recovery process, which is the main reason for its poor recyclability. The PXRD pattern and SEM image show the pristine and constructed hierarchical porous structures are both well preserved after catalytic cycling (c,d). As shown in d,e, the BET surface area and pore size distribution of HP-ZIF-8–20 (400, 4) after reaction are about 1634 m2 g–1 and 7 nm, respectively, which are not much different from those before reaction.
